bibl.title: Letter from Burton J. Hendrick to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 16, 1924

div1.p: Hendrick agrees to publish Kean's letter, which challenged Marie Gorgas' account of her husband's yellow fever work, in the journal World's Work.

div1.head: Letter from Burton J. Hendrick to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 16, 1924
div1.opener:
3 copies
THE WORLD'S WORK
GARDEN CITY NEW YORK
April 16, 1924.
My dear Colonel Kean,
div1.p:
I shall be glad to publish in the WORLD'S
WORK the correction contained in your letter.
It will appear in an early number. I regret
very much that the necessity of condensing this
chapter produced a result which has given pain
to Mrs. Reed. In the original version Dr. Reed's
work is described in detail and particular em-
phasis laid upon the fact that Gorgas' chief
claim to fame is that he put into operation so
successfully the Reed discovery. Another man
who suffers rather severely is Dr. Carter whose
work is also described in detail but of whom
practically no mention is made in the magazine
article. Such lapses as this are inevitable in
magazine publication.
With many thanks for the tone of your note,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Burton J. Hendrick Col. J. R. Kean,
Headquarters First Corps Area,
Army Base,
Boston 9, Mass.
